title: Seedcamp
segmentation: Thank you all 20 of you for being in the room at this hour.
I'm going to be very quick.
I'm going to go through this very fast.
I just wanted to talk a little bit about Seedcamp.
So it's an initiative that we started last year.
It's all about helping European entrepreneurs and companies start up and get off the ground.
So it's all about catalyzing the next generation of you.

In technology entrepreneurs, you know I covered this a little bit in when when I was talking on the panel before we really feel Europe is a fantastic place to start a business and so not everybody has to run away and an leave Europe to really build a big company so you know, as I said, eight of the top 11 broadband markets UK advertisers spend twice as much as as they do in the US and it's growing at a faster rate than the US market.
There is an amazing amount of talent, an actually you know this region and sort of Russia or Ukraine are really important to us.
'cause we see a lot of lot of great developers and math talent in these regions.
So really fantastic talent.
I think what's missing for Europe though has been kind of the rock stars so the the Google guys or the Microsoft Guys Yahoo a little less.
So maybe today of who really made it out there and so that's when that's what we want to help build is kind of the rock stars of of European.
Intrapreneurs I I'm going to just skip through all of this.
You know we build a lot of great power.
Full inherent technologies venture the venture communities really matured in the past 20 years.
Starting to see a lot more records being broken in terms of how much investment.
Is going into early stage ventures.
And you're seeing some great exits starting to to come up.
So just in the past couple of years with the Swedish Founders from my SQL to the London guys, last FM and and so on and so forth.
So you really you know you're really seeing some great great sort of hundreds of millions billion dollar exits happen.
And a lot of lot of web leaders in in the pipeline as well as well so you know those making those seeing a lot of sort of money coming in Hubbell hotel juice being very disrupt.
If so, lot of great companies in the pipeline lot of also.
Again we covered this a little bit in the panel.

And you know, if you're out there taking taking note of these names, they're actively reinvesting some of their success into into startup companies, and a lot of this activity we do see in Germany and around London.

So the the summer brothers Lucash the Founders Link guys are really heavily investing in in the Berlin area and the summer guys are also moving a lot in Poland as well, so and also around London from.
The last minute founders to the cheap flights guys.
They're really reinvesting in in startups also, so a lot of Angel investors are starting to starting to be pretty active.
But we really felt that there were three gaps still remaining.
One, as I said this before, which is VCs are starting to build larger funds and invest invest in growth stage companies a lot more and kind of moving up the food chain.
So there's there's still a dearth of capital we felt at the very early stage, and when I say that we're talking about kind of the 50,000 to the hundreds of thousands of euros of investment.
Secondly, it's it's really hard to rise above the noise, so.
I think you know people mentioned.
Is there a bubble and you're there's a lot of activity in startups all all around Web 2.0, and so it's a very.
It's a very popular area and it's it's hard for companies to really stand out and and show what you know.
Some of the innovative things they're building and Thirdly is how does a first time entrepreneur really get access to top tier VC's or recruiters or lawyers?
Also kind of the.

Also really experts in product and tech development, so you know a lot of that's much easier to access in the Valley, and we felt that that was missing here as well as that complete sort of ecosystem.
So that's how, seedcamp.
Born.
As I mentioned before, it's a competition plus a fund, plus events that we do like today where we go out on the road a lot across Europe talking about what we're doing at seedcamp.
Essentially we have.
I've kind of pulled it out a few terms here, which is where pan European.
It's all about kind of the main week and three months of support that we provide to to the companies, and it's about initial funding to get your company off the ground.
But it's really the power is in the community that we're bringing together.
So during that week we expose companies 220 of the top sort of European mentors that if you look on our website, it's a cross product experts, tech, guys, corporates, VCs, lawyers.
You know every everybody.
Um?
What we're looking for, I'll actually get more into the detail of seekamp.
What are we looking for?
We're looking for sort of teams of two to two to four Guys girls.
At least half the team should be very techie and ideally the other half should be pretty business savvy.

We're also looking for ideas that are focused on Internet, mobile software, open source, 'cause the whole idea is that we want to prove in a very short time, three months that you can really develop from a prototype stage to be able to go to market.
And it's a lot harder to do that in.
Obviously, in big CapEx, CapEx related investments, like in biotech or or chipsets, so the model is very specific to what's happening in in the web, web or mobile space.
And we're looking at everything from companies that are just at the prototype stage to those who have a product developed.
So you know, we are.
We just really want to be the go to community for very early stage.
First time entrepreneurs were thinking, how do I?
How do I get to world stage when I'm just kind of at something where I've built it on my kind of home computer and really taking it out?
So how does it work?

I won't go into much much of this given time, but there's the whole application selection process were were all about being very transparent, so you can find all the information on our website, but essentially the applications will open up in June through August and we have a panel of VCs that will look at all the applications.
We got 270 applications last year realized that it will probably grow a lot more than number, but will scale for that and.
We'll select 20 teams to come to London for one week, so that's this.
The seed funding time where you're exposed to that whole community out of that will choose five companies or more to actually make an investment in two.
It's 50,000 euros for 10% equity, and we're playing around with the model a little bit.
So if you think if you're a little bit later stage, don't worry about applying.
We're looking to tweak the model as well, and.
After after the five companies we support them for the three months and it's intense.
It's like you live, eat, breathe your business.
So you've got to be really passionate about what you're doing and where.
Last year we invited teams to come to London for 3 three months.
This year we're requiring teams to come to London for three months, because if you talk to undress will talk a little bit later.

But if you talk to Samantha, it's just all about really leveraging all the connections we're putting out there, and so that three months is critical for you to be on the ground constantly to be able to.
Be at kind of world class events and all the all the people were introducing you to from the US through the UK community.
Also something you were doing this year is really going to try to have an event out in California.
And so as I said, it's if you're building a global company, it's a hard one to not ever visit the Valley or London.
And so we're going to take teams out to the US on a bit of a Rd show as well.
So we think that's pretty important and the seat camp.
On the road bit is kind of what we do is just spreading the name of seedcamp and the community.
These are all our backers, so it's the leading Tier 1 VC community in in Europe.
And all the kind of all the mentors who are there lot of recognizable names.
I hope so.
It's across people who have who have started and sold massive companies to really usability experts, which is critical when you're launching a consumer product to a few of our friends.
We have incredible access to Tech Crunch and the FT and Reuters and so on and so forth.
And you know, really, really good friendships with Google and Microsoft.
Google's been amazing at every event that we.
We were at.
They provide a lot of experts across any kind of area.
We're looking for.
Whether it's biz dev or product API guys.
Whatever it is so.
Just a lot of great friends.
How do the companies benefit very quickly?
It's really intense.
As I said, there's a lot of weekly events that happen.

There's two key milestones which are all about showing what your product is after six weeks and then going to Investor Day after 11 weeks and four out of the six companies raised their next round of funding within that three month period.
So that's you know, hugely successful to go from 50,000 euros to they raise between 1/4 million and a million euros.
So huge sort of benefit in that three months.
Thing probably is the teams have said to us they've they've cut their development time from 18 months to kind of six months, so you know, you really get to develop your product a lot faster.
So what we're looking for is even higher quality of applications this year.
So if you really think you've got an amazing idea and Anna think about building that product, please do 'cause we're really looking for.
As we said, sort of Google of Europe.
Or you know, a kind of world class idea, less MBAs, more more.
Kind of more techie, more hackers.
So I think the crowd you've assembled here in the past two days is perfect and so in terms of getting involved with us, look at our website.

Tap into our community, which is on Facebook you Noodle, which is a fantastic community for entrepreneurs by entrepreneurs and just yet so it's, you know, find us on the web and I you can write to info at seedcamp and it comes to me and so I can answer any questions you have or find me after this and that's that's.
That's all seedcamp so that's it for me, thanks.
Oh, and I think we're going to do kewene anyways, right?
OK. Yep.
Do we, sorry?
I didn't understand it.
Yep, I hope so.
I mean, that's that's kind of the what we've done.
Yeah, we think you know we.
We think I think we missed some too in our round of 20 and the six that we put it put money into we think are really cool, interesting companies.
So one of the I mean we've sort of gotten some critique on that.
Some of the companies look a lot like what you've people have started in the US.
But actually I think you have to recognize sometimes that they've developed at similar times as startups did in the US.

But some of the US companies raised their money sooner than the European companies, so but you know, we constantly want to improve the quality of the ideas and teams, and that's why that's why I'm going out on the road a lot to talk about some of the areas that are exciting for us and that we want to see more companies into, which is, as I've said, sort of consumer finance space in touch, touch screen technologies to enterprise 2.0.
So you know, ideas around that are particularly interesting.
Other questions.
Well, turn it over to a much more dynamic speaker with and rush.
